Award.AbstractNarration:
Witnessing the formation of the first galaxies is one of the key goals of extragalactic astrophysics. Astronomers wish to understand when galaxies first emerge, what physical processes regulate their early evolution, and to what extent their star formation drives the subsequent evolution of the universe. The research enabled by this NSF award will fundamentally resolve long-standing questions about the makeup of the universe in its first billion years, and it will form the bedrock of future studies with ground- and space-based telescopes.

This program has three components. The PI and his team will (1) perform a survey of large sample of low mass star-forming galaxies at 2 < z < 4 using optical spectrographs on the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), Magellan, Keck, and Very Large Telescope (VLT) observatories. They will also (2) compare emission line properties of low mass galaxies to those predicted from large grid of photoionization models. Finally, the team will (3) perform a transformative study to search for [CIII] and other rest-UV emission lines in z > 6 galaxies using near-infrared spectrographs on the Keck, VLT, and LBT observatories.

The PI will also work with the Mount Lemmon Sky Center to build a 5-week curriculum on extragalactic astronomy for the newly-developed University of Arizona Sky Ambassador program. The program will link regional high school teachers to the many resources available at the University of Arizona, and will teach students the basics of stellar evolution and cosmology, while bringing to life commonly taught concepts in physics and chemistry classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emergence of the first stars, black holes, and galaxies marks a fundamental transition in the history of the universe. This early period has long been shrouded in mystery, out of the reach of our telescopes. But in the last decade, this has begun to change.  Images taken by the infrared camera on the Hubble Space Telescope have identified faint galaxies that are more than 13 billion light years away.  By studying the light from these distant objects, we are able to witness the universe as it was in its infancy, tracking the growth of the first galactic systems. Our most detailed view of these early galaxies is revealed by dispersing the light into a spectrum, revealing the telltale signature of chemical elements.  The properties of these elements offers unique insight into the nature of stars and black holes in the first generation of galactic systems. 

Unfortunately the first attempts to obtain spectra of early galaxies were largely  met with failure. In this project, we proposed and developed a new approach to characterizing the spectra of the first galaxies. Our technique focused on spectral features emitted by carbon and oxygen ions in the ultraviolet and optical part of the electromagnetic spectrum. Our observations proved successful, revealing emission from carbon and oxygen in galaxies in the first billion years of cosmic history. Surprisingly, the emission lines were found to be extremely strong, unlike almost any galaxy known previously. The implications of these findings are twofold. First, they suggest that the new technique proposed in this project is likely to be among the most effective ways of learning about the first galaxies in the early universe.  Plans for studying the most distant galaxies with the next generation of 20-30 meter-class telescopes now largely revolve around the detection and characterization of these spectral features.  Second, these findings suggest that the energetic sources in the earliest-known galaxies are significantly different from those at later cosmic epochs.  To understand why, we have developed techniques to distinguish the powering mechanism of the line emission, distinguishing between very hot stars and the accretion of matter onto supermassive black holes. Our work demonstrates that in most cases, stars are likely responsible for powering the observed spectral features.  We present observations that demonstrate that early galaxies tend to have stars that are both younger and more chemically-pristine than those several billion years later. The combination of these two effects leads to a stellar population that is extremely high in temperature, powering the intense spectral features that we have observed.
